comments.author: Heather
comments.content: I really like lemon and rosemary together. These sound great! And pretty photos as always.

comments.author: Crystal
comments.content: Yum! Chickpeas are a favorite of mine and I'm always looking for more ways to use them. Thank you!

comments.author: Katherine
comments.content: Yes please!

comments.author: Lara Alexander
comments.content: these look great. I like falafel, but don't usually deep fry at home, so never make them. I would make these though! Thanks for the recipe.

comments.author: Striving Bean
comments.content: Wow, my mouth is watering.  Delicious way to cook with chickpeas!

comments.author: Ali - YumVeggieBurger
comments.content: Yum! I never thought of using rosemary with chickpeas before...

comments.author: Katie
comments.content: Looks like a tasty source of protein. :)  This would be a good alternative to trying to make falafels.

comments.author: Cookin' Canuck
comments.content: What a great hit of protein and a very original way to use summertime tomatoes.

comments.author: Veggie Belly
comments.content: These chickpea cakes took so filling and tasty. I love the sesame here. Have you tried baking these?

comments.author: Michael Natkin
comments.content: @veggiebelly - I haven't tried baking them; I sure it would work but you probably wouldn't get the same degree of delicious crispiness.

comments.author: Appetite for Conversation
comments.content: My mother-in-law is coming in town, and since she eats VERY differently from us it's always a little tricky to cook for her.  These just might do the trick!

comments.author: ben
comments.content:
these were great, loved by all. Made them Friday night along with the tomato jam. can't wait to make them and eat them again.

thanks for all you do!

delicious ......

comments.author: alicia
comments.content: Aside from the tomato jam, what else would you serve these with, if it were the main entree?

comments.author: Michael Natkin
comments.content: Hey Alicia - Great question! My first thought would be couscous or a rice pilaf, maybe flavored with preserved lemon, and an Israel or Greek style salad.

comments.author: Michelle
comments.content: I made these tonight and they were out of this world!  Seriously.  So good.  The tomato jam was the perfect compliment too.  I made roasted asparagus with it and called it dinner!  Even my four-year-old ate it!  I know I'll be craving these often in the future so the recipe is going in my binder to keep :-)

comments.author: Michael Natkin
comments.content: Roasted asparagus sounds like a perfect accompaniment. Thanks so much for taking the time to write and let me know you liked the cakes and tomato jam!

comments.author: Lauren
comments.content: I have always been wary of chickpeas. I have friends that toss them over salad but I have never been on board with this practice, so when my when my friend found this recipe and suggested I use it for a dinner party last week I was hesitant to say the least. But I decided to indulge her and was pleasantly surprised. They were delicious! I am definitely adding this to my book of Appetizer Recipes. I work with Better Recipes but I had yet to come across a recipe like this. I have been recommending it all my other anti-chickpea friends and trying to convert them as well!

comments.author: Michael Natkin
comments.content: Glad to hear we've made another garbanzo convert :)!

comments.author: Natalie
comments.content: These were amazing!   My boyfriend surprised me one night  by making me this wonderful dish, and we ate the entire batch between the two of us.  We didn't have the ingredients for tomato jam, but they were very good with a little hot sauce. Thank you for giving us a new go-to recipe!

comments.author: Reena
comments.content: i'm planning a casino themed party for my husband's birthday and think this would be great for one of two vegetarian mains since they would work so well as "poker chips"!  silly question though.. could i substitute panko for breadcrumbs?  would it change the flavour or consistency?

comments.author: Michael Natkin
comments.content:
The issue with panko in this recipe is that the breadcrumbs are used on the interior, not as a breading. I think that panko would serve that same function of absorbing moisture and adding a bit of fluffiness, but I'm not completely sure. If you try it, let us know how it turns out!


Thanks,
Michael

comments.author: EGKate
comments.content: I made these with panko last night. They were delicious, but the texture was not great. My guess is that the texture was off because I processed them for a bit too long rather than the use of panko, though. I'll have to try them a second time to be sure.

comments.author: mim
comments.content:
oooooh, yay, my mom just gave me a bunch of home canned garbanzos, so i am searching for good recipes to try. i'm excited to make these patties to use as garden burgers! 

i'm hoping i will be able to freeze some .... advice on whether to try this prior to frying or after?? i would think before, so i can get a crispy outside after thawing?

thanks for the recipe.

comments.author: Michael Natkin
comments.content: Agreed, if I was going to freeze them, I'd do it before. I might just freeze the whole batch and defrost and scoop when it is time to fry.

comments.author: mim
comments.content:
what a lightening fast response! thanks so much. 

and now that i've looked around your blog some more, thanks for this really fantastic resource! bookmarked! lots of recipes i want to try already. :)

comments.author: cyg
comments.content: Can't really understand the great reviews by the people who have actually made these.  I followed the recipe exactly and found the chickpea cakes VERY VERY bland...maybe the lemon i used was too small to provide the right amount of juice and zest to bring out the flavors...Maybe i'll try this again some time, perhaps with some extra lemon zest and perhaps a bit of crushed red paper.  But not too excited about these as written...
